Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling Engineered Levers for the 21st Century Teaching of STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research in biology has become increasingly mathematical, but high school courses in biology use little mathematics. To address this concern, this project will develop three replacement units for biology and refine them through classroom testing. The units will be models of STEM integration by using the important concepts of proportional reasoning and algebraic thinking and engineering re-design to address big ideas in science while also promoting the learning of 21st century skills. The materials build on existing work on the use of model eliciting activities and focus science and technology instruction on high-stakes weaknesses in mathematics and science. They address the scaling issue as part of the core design work by developing small units of curriculum that can be applied by early adopters in each context. The materials will undergo many rounds of testing and revision in the early design process with at least ten teachers each time. The materials will be educative for teachers, and the teacher materials and professional development methods will work at scale and distance.

Learning of science content will be measured through the use of existing instruments in wide use. Existing scales of task values, achievement goals and interest are used to measure student motivation. The work performed is guided by a content team; a scaling materials team; a scaling research team; the PI team of a cognitive scientist, a robotics educator, and a mathematics educator specializing in educational reform at scale; and the summative evaluation team lead by an external evaluator.

There is great interest in understanding whether integrated STEM education can interest more students in STEM disciplines. The focus on mathematics integrated with engineering in the context of a science topic is interesting and novel and could contribute to our understanding of integrating mathematics, engineering and science. The development team includes a cognitive scientist, a mathematics educator, teachers and scientists. The issues and challenges of interdisciplinary instruction will be investigated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biology is often thought of as the last refuge for the mathematically-averse: I like science but I don't like math, so I should study biology. However, in modern biology (as students now see in college), mathematics has actually become just as important for biology as for chemistry and physics. Also, mathematics is an important thinking tool for understanding some biology concepts, even the basic ones taught in high school biology. For example, understanding basic Mendelian inheritance involves understanding basic probability of combinations. Similarly, understanding population change that occurs through natural selection involves understanding emergent phenomena with a statistical basis.

Our project investigated whether high school biology learning can be improved by bringing in mathematics in a new way, a way that increases student understanding of biology big ideas and also increases student excitement about science. We developed two units that were each roughly 6-to-8 weeks long in length that would be used instead of the regular curriculum chapters. One unit covered biological inheritance (why do off-spring sometimes look different than their parents?), and the other unit covered population change with natural selection (what causes whole populations of organisms to change characteristics over time?). For both units, students were challenged with an engineering problem to solve over the course of the unit. For example, in the inheritance unit, students were asked to develop a breeding plan for a zoo working on a limited budget: how could they buy inexpensive common geckos and breed them into (much more expensive) rare geckos with different skin coloration?

To solve these problems, students had to make mathematical predictions. Students gradually built up their understanding of the biology concepts and mathematical equations by looking at patterns in data, proposing explanations, and testing their explanations against existing and new data.

Across several studies with large numbers of teachers and students across two states, we found that students learned almost twice as much using these new materials as did students who experienced traditional biology instruction from equally competent teachers. We also found that very typical high school biology teachers could keep up these excellent student learning outcomes even when the teachers did not get (hard to do at scale) face-to-face support from the development team; instead, teachers could do well even if they had to download the materials from an online website, and learn how to implement these new materials using carefully designed teachers guidelines and interact with other teachers using a website.

Both students and teachers found this more rigorous way of approaching biology challenging and often frustrating. At the same time, it made biology a more interesting topic to study, in part because they were asked to think rather than just memorize biology ideas, and in part because they worked on an application of the science knowledge.

Along the way, much was learned about important factors in making these kinds of units effective for students and teachers, including what kinds of instructions and resources are most helpful for teachers to make useful changes to the materials to support the unique needs of their students. For example, we learned about how to use classroom video effectively, and how to get teachers to see the difference between students parroting back a memorized answer and students solving science problems using their own thinking.
